summary: Reolink Video Doorbell Wi-Fi (DB_566128M5MP_W) performs insufficient validation of firmware update signatures, allowing remote attackers to upload malicious images and achieve root RCE.
Reolink Video Doorbell Wi-Fi exposes an unsecured UART serial console that grants direct root shell access without authentication to attackers with physical access.
Dahua ONVIF request handler stack-based buffer overflow allowing unauthenticated remote code execution (RCE) via crafted packets.
Hikvision HikCentral Professional access control bypass allowing unauthenticated remote attackers to gain full administrative privileges.
Axis Camera Station Pro and Device Manager critical remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability via the proprietary 'Remoting' protocol.
AVTECH IP cameras and NVRs authentication bypass in the 'streamd' web server via URL manipulation (e.g., /nobody/..).
Hikvision Integrated Security Management Platform deserialization vulnerability via Fastjson, leading to unauthenticated RCE.
TP-Link Tapo Android app contains a privilege escalation vulnerability where interacting with a 'low battery' notification on a shared device grants full power control permissions.
TP-Link Tapo C500 Wi-Fi cameras contain a hardcoded RSA private key in the firmware, enabling man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks against device communications.
FNKvision Y215 CCTV Camera critical weakness in /etc/passwd handling allowing unauthenticated root access.
Edimax IC-7100 and related IoT devices allow unauthenticated remote code execution, actively exploited by Mirai botnets.
D-Link DCS-932L stack-based buffer overflow via setSystemEmail parameter allows unauthenticated RCE.
PTZOptics camera authentication bypass allows unauthenticated remote attackers to overwrite configuration and gain control.
Axis Camera Station Pro privilege escalation via file deletion redirect during service restart.
TP-Link Kasa EC70 Spot Pan Tilt cameras contain a stack-based buffer overflow in the authentication header, allowing unauthenticated remote code execution as root.
Hanwha Vision (Samsung) cameras (A/X/P series) are vulnerable to Denial of Service (DoS) via empty UDP packets sent to the WS-Discovery service.
Imou GO (Dahua) Android app arbitrary file download vulnerability.
D-Link DCS-8300LHV2 ONVIF command injection via malicious XML timezone parameters.
ABUS TVIP cameras allow RCE via /cgi-bin/mft/wireless_mft.
Bosch IP cameras command injection for authenticated administrators.
Ubiquiti Edge devices allow remote code execution through crafted HTTP requests.
TP-Link Tapo C310 cameras (firmware 1.3.0) use hardcoded RTSP credentials, allowing any unauthenticated network user to view the live video feed.
Reolink RLC-410W cameras allow unauthenticated information disclosure via the 'netserver' service, leaking device configuration details.
Vivotek cameras allow remote command injection through crafted CGI parameters.
OpenHarmony OS (used in various smart cameras) authentication bypass in multimedia subsystem.
Hikvision cameras and NVRs command injection vulnerability in the web server component.
ThroughTek Kalay P2P SDK remote code execution vulnerability affects millions of IoT devices (Wyze, OEM cams).
Reolink IP cameras allow authentication bypass via predictable session tokens.
Uniview NVR allows remote code execution via crafted RPC call.
Dahua cameras allow remote command execution via crafted ONVIF requests.
Ubiquiti UniFi Video cameras vulnerable to authentication bypass on the management API.
Hanwha Techwin Wisenet devices allow stack-based buffer overflow via crafted HTTP request.
Reolink P2P cameras do not sufficiently protect data transfers, allowing attackers to reconstruct cleartext video/audio streams from captured P2P traffic.
Foscam cameras vulnerable to stack overflow via RTSP DESCRIBE command.
Uniview devices vulnerable to authentication bypass in web management interface.
Geovision GV-Control Center stack-based buffer overflow allowing RCE.
Axis network cameras allow remote code execution due to insufficient sanitisation of the action parameter.
Amazon Ring Video Doorbell Pro mishandles encryption during setup, allowing nearby attackers to intercept Wi-Fi credentials and spoof video feeds.
Google Nest Cam IQ Indoor (Weave protocol) allows brute-forcing of the pairing code, potentially giving an attacker full control over the device.
Arlo Base Stations (VMB4000/5000) lack sufficient physical protection on the UART interface, allowing attackers with physical access to obtain a root shell.
Arlo Base Stations expose a 'passthru' API endpoint that allows authenticated users to upload arbitrary files, leading to potential code execution.
Multiple Dahua OEM products allow remote command execution due to improper authentication.
Hanwha Techwin (Samsung) NVRs allow a system crash and reboot (DoS) by submitting a username exceeding 117 characters.
Hanwha Techwin (Samsung) SmartCam devices allow remote code execution with root privileges due to improper input validation in the media server.
Hanwha Techwin (Samsung) SmartCam devices allow authentication bypass, enabling attackers to register new administrative accounts without credentials.
Axis Camera Station and device firmware vulnerable to directory traversal allowing arbitrary file read.
TBK/Novo/Many-OEM DVRs authentication bypass via Cookie: uid=admin.
Hikvision devices (and LaView/Annke OEMs) expose backdoor credentials allowing unauthenticated remote access.
Amcrest cameras expose telnet interface with hardcoded credentials allowing root access.
Grandstream cameras contain hidden telnet backdoor credentials enabling full compromise.
Vivotek (and LaView OEM) cameras contain a buffer overflow in the RTSP service, allowing remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via long strings.
